channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Who Would Replace Kamala Harris in the Senate for California? Let the Jockeying Begin
item.description: As the Democratic vice-presidential nominee hits the campaign trail, a race to replace her kicks off.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Senator Kamala Harris is elected vice president, her rise will leave an opening for her seat in the United States Senate.

item.title: Protesters Blocked ICE Buses in Oregon. Federal Agents Responded in Force.
item.description: Using crowd-control weapons, agents were able to extract people who were detained on one of the buses after hundreds of protesters in Bend, Ore., blocked the vehicles from moving.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker

item.title: How Trump’s Push to Reopen Schools Backfired
item.description: Distrust of the president and his motives hardened the conviction of some educators that teaching in person was unsafe, helping drive union opposition.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: LM Otero/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mr. Trump said the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s guidelines on how to safely reopen schools were “impractical” and should be revised.

item.title: A Florida Sheriff Has Ordered His Deputies Not to Wear Masks
item.description: The sheriff forbade his deputies from wearing masks while on duty, with some exceptions, and also barred visitors to his offices from wearing them.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: More states and cities are moving to require face coverings. In Miami Beach, Fla., above, officials have issued more than $14,000 in fines to people who have refused to wear masks.

item.title: How Biden Chose Harris: A Search That Forged New Stars, Friends and Rivalries
item.description: Joe Biden winnowed a large list of candidates to four finalists before settling on Kamala Harris, in a process shaped by questions of loyalty. He is eyeing other contenders for top administration jobs.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: No candidate scored as highly as Senator Kamala Harris on the Biden campaign’s core criteria for a running mate, including her strength as a debater and ability to help him win the White House.

item.title: Biden, Seizing on Masks as a Campaign Issue, Calls for a Mandate
item.description: Joe Biden said wearing a mask was “about your responsibilities as an American” as he and his new running mate, Kamala Harris, drew a contrast with President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. with Senator Kamala Harris on Thursday at a briefing on Covid-19 from public health experts.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Deaths are climbing in the U.S., and data suggests the official toll is an undercount.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: U.S. Labels Chinese Language Education Group a Diplomatic Mission
item.description: State Department officials said the move was aimed at informing American schools of potential propaganda from the government group’s programs, largely known as Confucius Institutes.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the Trump administration was seeking “fair and reciprocal treatment” from the Chinese government on creating open access to educational resources.

item.title: In Derecho’s Wake, More Than 250,000 in Midwest Struggle Without Power
item.description: Residents in Iowa, Illinois and surrounding states were still without electricity days after Monday’s storms brought hurricane-force winds.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch, Aimee Ortiz and John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Andy Abeyta/The Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Laurie Berdahl among downed limbs at her home in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, this week after a derecho wind storm.

item.title: Anxiety and Depression Rises Among Young Adults, Blacks and Latinos in Pandemic
item.description: A new C.D.C. survey indicates that young people, as well as Blacks and Latinos of all ages, are showing signs of deteriorating mental health and some are resorting to substance abuse.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Cam Bonelli/The Hattiesburg American, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A freshman dorm at the University of Southern Mississippi last week.

item.title: Pompeo Says He and Military Warned Russia on Bounties for Killing U.S. Troops
item.description: The secretary of state’s acknowledgment came as a new detail surfaced about the intelligence that led to the C.I.A. assessment.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Igor Kupljenik/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: “If the Russians are offering money to kill Americans or, for that matter, other Westerners as well, there will be an enormous price to pay,” Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said.

item.title: Justice Dept. Accuses Yale of Discrimination Against White, Asian-American Applicants
item.description: The department’s civil rights division accused the university of violating the Civil Rights Act by discriminating against Asian-American and white applicants.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:credit: Andrew Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Yale University campus in New Haven, Conn. Yale is the second Ivy League school the Trump administration has confronted over its admissions policies.

item.title: Tropical Storm Josephine Forms in the Atlantic
item.description: The 10th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, Josephine is not expected to hit the Caribbean islands or the mainland United States, according to the National Hurricane Center.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: NOAA
item.media:description: Tropical Storm Josephine formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Thursday. “Right now, we don’t expect this to be a land threat,” a meteorologist said.

item.title: Winning the Right to Vote Was the Work of Many Lifetimes
item.description: It took generations of women — mothers and daughters, leaders and followers — to secure the 19th Amendment.
item.dc:creator: Kate Clarke Lemay

item.title: Don’t Like What You See on Zoom? Get a Face-Lift and Join the Crowd
item.description: Cosmetic surgeons say business is booming after elective surgery opened up, with quarantine proving a time to heal in secrecy from renovation of face and body.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrice Solorzano, right, and her daughter, Jena, each took advantage of the solitude of quarantine to get cosmetic surgeries.

item.title: You Probably Won’t Catch the Coronavirus From Frozen Food
item.description: Reports that the virus was detected in a trans-continental shipment of frozen chicken wings sparked concerns online. But experts aren’t worried.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Nataliia Rumiantseva/Alamy
item.media:description: Samples taken from chicken tested positive for coronavirus RNA, but that doesn’t mean the virus was transmissible.

item.title: Trump Eliminates Major Methane Rule, Even as Leaks Are Worsening
item.description: The weakening of Obama-era efforts to fight climate change amounts to a gift to many oil companies. Researchers warn that the decision ignores science.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Jessica Lutz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rollback marks the last major Obama-era climate-change regulation to be weakened by the administration.

item.title: Fortnite Creator Sues Apple After Game Is Banned From App Store
item.description: Epic Games, the maker of the popular game, provoked Apple by violating its policies, then released a social media campaign and lawsuit to confront the tech giant.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Kellen Browning and Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Epic Games
item.media:description: Fortnite has become an enormous enterprise, and Epic Games announced in May that it had more than 350 million registered players.

item.title: Daimler to Settle U.S. Emissions Charges for $2.2 Billion
item.description: The agreement is a small fraction of the sum that Volkswagen paid after admitting to emissions cheating in 2015.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daimler is settling charges that it programmed Mercedes-Benz cars and trucks to cheat on emissions tests.

item.title: U.S. Seizes Bitcoin Said to Be Used to Finance Terrorist Groups
item.description: ISIS and other groups openly solicited virtual currency donations because they mistakenly believed that the transactions would be anonymous, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Mohammed Saber/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: American officials seized illicit funding for terrorist groups including Hamas’ paramilitary arm, the Al Qassam Brigades.

item.title: What Phil Collins and the YouTube Twins Tell Us About Music
item.description: The brothers Tim and Fred Williams have wowed the internet with their YouTube reactions to vintage music. Why are generation-spanning videos like theirs so popular right now?
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Phil Collins resurfaced in a big way when twins from Gary, Ind., posted to their YouTube channel an animated video of themselves listening for the first time to his 1981 song “In the Air Tonight.”

item.title: Supreme Court Lets Rhode Island Make Voting by Mail Easier Amid Pandemic
item.description: The court rejected a request from Republicans to block an order suspending a requirement that witnesses or a notary observe the completion of absentee ballots.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Steven Senne/Associated Press
item.media:description: A voter placing her ballot in a secure box during the primary election in Providence, R.I., in June.

item.title: Salt Lake City Suspends Use of Police Dogs in Arrests After Black Man Is Bitten
item.description: The Police Department said that the use of the dogs in arrests would be suspended until the city could review its policies and practices.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Salt Lake City Police Department
item.media:description: Police Officer Nickolas Pearce ordered his dog to bite Jeffery Ryans after Mr. Ryans had surrendered with his hands in the air.

item.title: Israel and United Arab Emirates Strike Major Diplomatic Agreement
item.description: President Trump announced that Israel and the United Arab Emirates would establish “full normalization of relations” and that in exchange Israel would forgo for now “declaring sovereignty” over occupied West Bank territory.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Isabel Kershner, David D. Kirkpatrick and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: “Things are happening that I can’t talk about,” but they are amazing, President Trump told reporters on Thursday.

item.title: In N.Y.C.’s Spring Virus Surge, a Frightening Echo of 1918 Flu
item.description: In March and April, death rates rivaled those seen during the country’s deadliest pandemic, a new study finds. “What 1918 looked like is basically this.”
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman/The New York Times
item.media:description: A temporary morgue outside New York City’s medical examiner’s office in April.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From Kamala Harris’s First Full Day on the Biden Ticket
item.description: She is adding sizzle, bringing in lots of cash, carving out an anti-Trump role and seemingly confounding the Republican opposition.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris have a yearslong relationship that dates back to her days as California’s attorney general, which overlapped with the late Beau Biden’s time as attorney general in Delaware.

item.title: What Are the Plans for Reopening California Schools? Here's What to Know
item.description: Thursday: The year has started out looking different across the state. Also: A dangerous fire in northern Los Angeles County.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Gregory Bull/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Hoover High School principal, Jason Babineau, waited for class of 2020 graduates on a makeshift stage in front of the school on Tuesday in San Diego.

item.title: Harris crystallizes Trump’s view of women: They’re ‘nasty’ or housewives.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kamala Harris drew immediate attacks from President Trump and other Republicans.

item.title: The Democratic contenders pledge a path forward out of crises.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris appeared together for the first time as running mates in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday.

item.title: Kamala Harris Offers a Preview of What She’ll Bring
item.description: The new running mate played both defense and offense: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: The Rise of QAnon
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Yar and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith/Reuters
item.media:description: Back the Blue rally in Brooklyn on Sunday.

item.title: Will the Coronavirus Cancel Halloween?
item.description: Cities, towns, retailers and confectioners across the country are bracing themselves for more subdued festivities this year — if they have them at all.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Many people feel that Halloween celebrations are more important than ever this year.

item.title: California Becomes First State to Report 600,000 Cases: Live Updates
item.description: Five communities in South Texas have become leading hot spots in the United States. Fewer new jobless claims and a rising deficit could further hamper stimulus talks.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Why Mike Pence Should Be Worried About Debating Kamala Harris
item.description: The story of her career can be explained, in part, by a series of dramatic moments during congressional hearings and primary debates. Here are five of them.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris’s questioning of Attorney General William Barr in May 2019 demonstrated her prosecutorial prowess.

item.title: On Native American Land, Contact Tracing Is Saving Lives
item.description: As the coronavirus spread on the Fort Apache reservation in Arizona, medical teams sought out residents who might have been exposed. The effort paid off in unexpected ways.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata and Tomás Karmelo Amaya
item.media:credit: Tomás Karmelo Amaya for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Ryan Close, left, an Indian Health Services physician, and J.T. Nashio, a community health worker, checked on Judie Declay, who lives on the Fort Apache reservation.

item.title: Indian-Americans Cheer Kamala Harris’s Selection
item.description: Indian-American political leaders and community advocates described the choice of Ms. Harris as the Democratic vice-presidential nominee as a powerful statement on American possibility.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:credit: Kamala Harris campaign, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kamala Harris, left, with her sister, Maya, and mother, Shyamala, in Berkeley, Calif., in 1970.

item.title: Facebook Will Promote Voting by Mail as Trump Attacks Method
item.description: The voter information hub, on Facebook and Instagram, will feature prompts to vote and reminders of key election deadlines.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Absentee ballots were prepared to be submitted at polling station in Mequon, Wis., on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden and Harris’s Incident-Free, Audience-Free Debut
item.description: For all the oddities endemic to a mid-virus presidential campaign, the pair’s maiden gathering reflected a scene that seemed entirely plausible, even predictable, a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: The candidates stood with their spouses and maintained social distancing at the end of their debut event together.

item.title: Black Women Asked Their Party for What They Wanted. What Happens After the Kamala Harris Pick?
item.description: Kamala Harris is the first woman of color on a major party ticket. For the women who helped get her here, the moment is joyful, and worrisome.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina and Evan Nicole Brown
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: Halliestine Zimmerman at her home in Mauldin, S.C., in 2019. “Finally,” she said of the Democrats, “they are letting us know they hear us.”

item.title: Ohio State Football Is Canceled. Will Trump Take the Hit?
item.description: The Big Ten Conference’s decision to cancel its football season reverberated across Ohio, where the Buckeyes’ football program looms large. Some voters blamed President Trump’s handling of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: College football serves as an autumn religion on campus and in rural areas of battleground states like Ohio where President Trump’s support runs deepest.

item.title: G.O.P.'s Raw Personal Attacks on Kamala Harris
item.description: ‘Radical leftist’ or not progressive enough? In the hours after Ms. Harris’s announcement as Joe Biden’s vice president, the Trump campaign struggled to launch a clear attack on the Biden-Harris ticket.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Monday. On Wednesday he took aim at Senator Kamala Harris after her announcement as Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate.
